review_preview: Hidden behind a fabulous tapas bar, is a treasure amongst the restaurants in Madrid. I can't reward this establishment enough for their wonderful service and delicious meals. I've already been here twice in my month stay at Madrid. Their ventresca de atún is phenomenal. I...
review_full: Hidden behind a fabulous tapas bar, is a treasure amongst the restaurants in Madrid. I can't reward this establishment enough for their wonderful service and delicious meals. I've already been here twice in my month stay at Madrid. Their ventresca de atún is phenomenal. I also particularly love their trigueros (green asparagus). The solomillo is delicious and cooked to perfection. Please make sure to make a reservation in advance as they tend to get full if you just pop in. The tapas here are delicious as well but the front does tend to get busy. Overall, strongly recommend!

review_preview: De Maria is an exclusive Restaurant where Celebrities, Football players and their wives dine regularly. For this very reason - you will have to book to avoid disappointment. It is very elegant, with very well laid out dining tables, separate dining areas, private funciton rooms,...
review_full: De Maria is an exclusive Restaurant where Celebrities, Football players and their wives dine regularly. For this very reason - you will have to book to avoid disappointment.  It is very elegant, with very well laid out dining tables, separate dining areas, private funciton rooms, and an open view kitchen/brasserie at the back. There is a small bar in the entrance for those who choose not to book.  Little details like the expensive crockery and cutlery, food served on warm plates, lighting that dims to give it a more private atmosphere, Dim lighting and the excellent service are all positive traits that come to mind when I think of this restaurant.  The prices used to be unaffordable to most, especially when you want to enjoy their highly-reputed meat, but as of recent years' they've cut back a bit due to the hard times. They've even got a very good lunch menu at an affordable price. This shows that the demand for high-flying expenses have diminished considerably in recent times, and so this place is really open for many more people. Starters are elegant and light, and the presentation is lovely too. Please try the Tomate, and the provoletta (melted cheese with crackers, this oen perhaps isn't so light!). The meat is the core competency of this place, which I've briefly described below, and the desserts are delicious. Try the Piña if you're feeling guilty, or simply let yourself go and try the ridiculously sweet panqueque!!! Ask for a Isla de Capri or Duquesa, which used to be my favourite dessert (no longer available but they somehow conjured one for us last time!). It is a profiterol with vanilla ice cream on top and a coat of melted chocolate and light custard - rather beautifully presented too. It is to die for!  The highlight of this place is the meat. Lomo Alto Fileteado, Chuletón, and Solomillo are all to die for. They use the best Argentinian meat and have it flame-grilled to your choice. The only added ingredient is salt, and I can say - hands down - that you will NOT eat better meat!

title_review: Probably one of the best meals we have ever had
review_preview: It's a funny time in Madrid this week with lots of restaurants closed for holiday. We spotted De Maria while walking the neighbourhood and was so glad we went in. The food was excellent I ordered the secreto iberico pork which was tender especially nice...
review_full: It's a funny time in Madrid this week with lots of restaurants closed for holiday. We spotted De Maria while walking the neighbourhood and was so glad we went in.  The food was excellent I ordered the secreto iberico pork which was tender especially nice with the apple chilly jam. The wife had a beautiful tender fillet steak. The staff were so helpful, we had never been to an Argentine restaurant before but they were happy to explain the ingredients to some of the delightful side dishes.  The free extras such as lemon sorbets and licor de unvitac made the meal extra special. The evening was finished off with a Tropical bird, which was a pineapple filled with creme brulee which out of this world. So glad we were staying close by to waddle home and will definitely return next year

title_review: One of our Top 3 Restaurants in all of Madrid !
review_preview: Excellent food, and great service ... especially with Ceda (Seda), our favorite server! My wife and I had the good fortune to live in Madrid for 2 years, and so we had plenty of experiences. We've been back in the U.S. now for 8 months,...
review_full: Excellent food, and great service ... especially with Ceda (Seda), our favorite server! My wife and I had the good fortune to live in Madrid for 2 years, and so we had plenty of experiences. We've been back in the U.S. now for 8 months, and we still yearn for those evening dinners, usually shared with friends, at De Maria on Felix Biox. The Food: the appetizers, then more appetizers, the steaks, the wine, then more wine, the deserts, and then the after dinner drinks ... wow! Relax and take your time as they do in Spain, usually 2 - 3 hours at dinner, and you will not regret it.

review_preview: Can it be I am the first to review this new restaurant on Trip Advisor?  It's a brand new restaurant only open for two weeks.I came to find it via a recommendation from top-rated Madrid restaurant Astor Gastro-place (No.4 on TA)  just down the...
review_full: Can it be I am the first to review this new restaurant on Trip Advisor? It's a brand new restaurant only open for two weeks. I came to find it via a recommendation from top-rated Madrid restaurant Astor Gastro-place (No.4 on TA) just down the street. I tried to get in to Astor, but they were full, so I asked them for a recommendation, and they sent me to Cedron. A little hard to find, but right in between Astor and Plaza de las Carros. In fact, I had a view of the Iglesia de San Andrés Apostol, (St Andrews Church,) right outside the window from my table. It's my last night in Madrid after five nights, and I was eager to find a nice place for my last meal. A place with nice ambiance, good food, and a proper seat. As a solo traveler, I was tired of standing to eat, or sitting at what amounts to little more than a spice rack shelf to eat my dinner. What a wonderful find to be able to sit at a proper table! And nice music to round out the mood. I knew i was in a good place when the server described my perfectly pale glass of chilled Rose' to be the color of "onion skin." Yes, she gets it! I only had two things...the Eggplant Hummus with Pomegranate and Feta Cheese, and the Fried Cerviche with shaved red onion on top, but both were just lovely. A perfect ending to my visit in Madrid. Thank you, Astor Gastro-place for the recommendation. I wish the new restaurant, Cedron, buena suerte!

review_preview: The concierge at our hotel, the Intercontinental Madrid set up a reservation at 5 Felix Boix location for us and said we would have a fabulous meal and he was right! This restaurant is located in the financial district not too far from Bernabeu stadium...
review_full: The concierge at our hotel, the Intercontinental Madrid set up a reservation at 5 Felix Boix location for us and said we would have a fabulous meal and he was right! This restaurant is located in the financial district not too far from Bernabeu stadium (home of Real Madrid FC) and by the types of cars that people arrived in and the well-to-do clients, it was certainly a high end place! We arrived at 9pm as the restaurant opened, and we were given a prime table outside. Then the surprises began including a cold gazpacho to start. We ordered a bottle of Roija, blue cheese and walnut salad followed by steaks. We should have split the salad as each was big enough for 3 people, but every bite was delicious and the steaks (filet mignon and Ribeye) were grilled perfectly and were some of the best we have ever eaten! Between each course was a new surprise - amuse bouche, champagne, sorbet and more, all complimentary! Sharing some dessert, we were treated to free limoncello and pacharan liqueurs to finish off our night! We had a wonderful relaxed dinner at a very reasonable price (compared to high end steak houses in North America) and would definitely go back to De Maria on our next visit to Madrid! The valet even ran out to the main road to summon a taxi to take us back to our hotel- great ambiance, great food, and great service!

title_review: Love the De Maria in Hortaleza
review_preview: My boyfriend and I have eaten at the de Maria on Calle Hortaleza multiple times and the food is always delicious.  We usually order the Caprese salad, the provoleto appetizer (grilled provolone), a chorizo and then we split a steak.  The appetizers and salads are...
review_full: My boyfriend and I have eaten at the de Maria on Calle Hortaleza multiple times and the food is always delicious. We usually order the Caprese salad, the provoleto appetizer (grilled provolone), a chorizo and then we split a steak. The appetizers and salads are filling enough that one steak is plenty. Their steaks are amazing. They are seasoned and grilled perfectly but are usually served medium rare so if you like your steak cooked more be sure to tell them. I have also had their grilled asparagus and patatas fritas, both of which are very good. Basically, you can't go wrong here. There is a nice wine selection and we enjoy the atmosphere and service. They also have menus in English.

title_review: De Maria in Hortaleza - probably my favorite restaurant in Madrid
review_preview: Since there's no entry per location and De Maria has quite a few of them, I have to clarify up front - my comments relate to their Hortaleza location. I've been also to both the Preciados and Correo locations, but they are a definite step...
review_full: Since there's no entry per location and De Maria has quite a few of them, I have to clarify up front - my comments relate to their Hortaleza location. I've been also to both the Preciados and Correo locations, but they are a definite step down from the De Maria Hortaleza restaurant. Why so? Well for starters, the Hortaleza location is the newest and best looking of the bunch. The dining room is very large, with high ceilings so you never smell smoke from the smoking section. The lighting is great - strong enough that you can read your menu, low enough that you can relax and eat comfortably. The bar area in front is great for a quick bite also - quite a few nights I've been there for their special, and you can get in and out pretty quick. The grill is far enough in front that the restaurant is not permeated with the smell of smoke (something I cannot say about El Gaucho - yikes) But back to the restaurant part. Service in this restaurant is outstanding. Full disclosure: it may help that I am argentinian and I can connect with the staff (which is close to 100% argentinian). It may also help that over two years I went to this place at least once or twice a month (which I must admit, is the way to go - gotta love the "glad to see you again" level of service is still alive somewhere and that regulars are treated like special customers). But I've also seen them serve other tables around me and I've noticed the same level of service - courteous, never pushy, always suggesting or correcting if someone overorders or is not sure what they want, always quick with a complimentary sorbet at the end of the meal.  The meat is also very good at this location - both the ojo de bife and the entrana are very tasty. I've even had the asado de tira (which can be tough and greasy if not cooked well) in multiple occasions and loved it every time. Good provoletas, nice and crisp empanadas, awesome fries - everything is on target. You won't find a truer argentine parrilla in Madrid.  Bonus points: as a solo diner, I've never felt unwelcome, rushed or anything less than fully appreciated here (and I've done my share of sunday lunches at De Maria, traveling on my own, as well as plenty of solo dining all around Madrid). In a city that can be downright rude to solo diners in many, many places; this is a welcome find. When I brought business associates from the US here, they were always impressed as well (again, me being a regular helped that along, I'm sure) So, if you have a hunger for argentine beef and want to have a good experience head to De Maria in Hortaleza. Tell the maitre d' that the crazy argentine who used to lunch alone on Sundays on asado de tira and fries while reading a book sent you - who knows, it may help along ;-)

title_review: The stupidest waste of 400 EURO ever
review_preview: After three free appetizers, one more elaborate and pointless than the other, the starters arrived. As lobster salads go, they were well executed. The main courses were rack of suckling pig (fair, forgettable) and veal shoulder. This was to all intents and purposes inedible, being...
review_full: After three free appetizers, one more elaborate and pointless than the other, the starters arrived. As lobster salads go, they were well executed. The main courses were rack of suckling pig (fair, forgettable) and veal shoulder. This was to all intents and purposes inedible, being cold, overcooked and tasteless at the same time. It felt like the third time someone had served the same crappy dish and had it sent back. The waiter carried 90% of the meal back into the kitchen, never asking if anything was wrong.  Add to this a sommelier whose chief objective is to denigrate your wine choices, and recommend something at twice the cost, and you pretty much get the drift. The place has all but turned us off Michelin-rated restaurants for good.

review_preview: We are no strangers to spending a lot of $ for dinner for exceptional food experiences.  We have been to five different Michelin starred restaurants in Spain in the past two weeks. This is the only one we felt was overpriced.  Perhaps it's because the...
review_full: We are no strangers to spending a lot of $ for dinner for exceptional food experiences. We have been to five different Michelin starred restaurants in Spain in the past two weeks. This is the only one we felt was overpriced. Perhaps it's because the restaurant is in a hotel. Service was surprisingly slow. Twice we asked to waiter to give us just a minute to decide something and he didn't return for 10 minutes each time. Food was creative, delicious, and lived-up to the advanced billing. On the other hand, it didn't feel particularly Spanish. We might have had similar dishes in NY or San Francisco. So yes it was an exceptional food experience, but if we are ever in Madrid again, we will come back to some of the other places we ate instead.

review_preview: We went on June 2013 to have an experience on a restaurant with Michelin stars (2 in this case). So we made a reservation for a dinner in Santceloni (located next door with the Hesperia Hotel at Paseo de la Castellana) with the degustation menu....
review_full: We went on June 2013 to have an experience on a restaurant with Michelin stars (2 in this case). So we made a reservation for a dinner in Santceloni (located next door with the Hesperia Hotel at Paseo de la Castellana) with the degustation menu.  I cannot say anything about the food but original, marvelous, fantastic. No negative points in my case. The combination of flavours is so well balanced that feels simply OK, like the normal way it should be, amazing. I was expecting large dishes with little food and in fact, most of them were like that, like just a hint of heaven. I was expecting also to be hungry afterwards, but, honestly, not, I was not. Fish and duck dishes were served as small portions but acted as complementary dishes for this purpose of not feeling hungry. Hors d'oeuvre were so delicious that you could have a meal just with them. And I must admit that I did not like that much the cold tomato soup with oyster.  The service is, of course, correct. All personnel, waiters, sommelier, maître d', etc. are so knowledgeable about the whole experience of a dinner, choice of wines, champagne, breads, cheese, etc. that you really feel in good hands. The atmosphere is elegant, comfortable and modern. Little could be said about a 2 Michelin star restaurant that you could have not read or heard anywhere else. The experience is simply overwhelming. But paying the bill too. Honestly, the food is grandiose, but the price is so exaggerated that feels even offensive. Yes, you pay for original recipes; yes, you pay for experts at your service; yes, you pay for perfection in the kitchen, but the difference in price between 98% perfection in other restaurants and 100% in here seems posh. Anyway, the best dinner ever...

title_review: Original and sooo tasty dishes in an up-market environment!
review_preview: Had a lunch at a lovely Spanish time of 3pm on December 31. Note that the restaurant is located in the basement of Hotel Hesperia and it is not indicated. We asked the receptionist who told us that it was closed! Finally she managed to...
review_full: Had a lunch at a lovely Spanish time of 3pm on December 31. Note that the restaurant is located in the basement of Hotel Hesperia and it is not indicated. We asked the receptionist who told us that it was closed! Finally she managed to call and tell us where to go and there, what a surprise! We found the best, friendliest and most efficient staff I have ever seen -by far, even for Starred restaurants benchmark. We chose the Gastronomic menu with the wine pairing (EUR 70) which I would recommend. The menu starts after 3 appetizers offered. Overall, I must say that all the dishes based on fish were above superlatives and the desserts were generous too. Not to miss for cheese lovers is the cheese selection (try the Spanish ones) which is amazing. Unfortunately because they had to get ready for the New Year's dinner, the service was quite speedy and we would have liked to stay a bit longer, and have a cigar (as you have to reserve apparently). But they did make up for it, offering us a bottle of their amazing olive oil especially made for them (we wanted to buy it anyway) which was a very nice gesture. Will be back!

review_preview: I had been wanting to come here for a number of years and had never managed despite visiting Madrid often. I was not disappointed. The tasting menu was, as one would imagine, excellent with the flight of wines being well considered. The whole experience is...
review_full: I had been wanting to come here for a number of years and had never managed despite visiting Madrid often. I was not disappointed. The tasting menu was, as one would imagine, excellent with the flight of wines being well considered. The whole experience is what you would expect from a 2 starred restaurant and I would not expect to write a bad review. All the staff have a distinct desire to give you the perfect dining experience. Each of my dishes was remarkable for the quality of its ingredients, the careful balance of its tastes and textures, the precise skill of its preparation and the painterly care of its presentation. A real experience for all five senses.  I would not opt for the tasting menu unless the entire table does so. It can becomes fussy and irritating for diners if not.  I can not wait to come back here. Having said all of this, prepare to pay a not insignificant sum of money to diner here!

title_review: First class restaurant - be prepared to spend lots of $$$
review_preview: I went here for my birthday in September. It's attached to a hotel outside of the city centre.PROs:- Exceptional service!  I'm not sure if it is because of it being a Michelin star rated restaurant or because my husband and I have been...
review_full: I went here for my birthday in September. It's attached to a hotel outside of the city centre. PROs: - Exceptional service! I'm not sure if it is because of it being a Michelin star rated restaurant or because my husband and I have been exposed to the impolite service we received in other average restaurants in Madrid! -There's a Metro stop one minute walk from the restaurant. -Beautifully plated food. It is truly like eating a piece of art! -Meals come with extra (very small portions) like amuse Bouche, appetizers, and plate of dessert. CONs: - It is away from the city centre. So if we wanted to take a stroll after dinner, there weren't anything nearby except a Metropolis full of buildings. - Quite expensive for the portion you receive. For example, I got the suckling pig for the Entree which costs €55 - on a plate were 5 square pieces of (mostly fat) meat 2" in size each.  - Similar to my point above, everything cost money including bread - which by the way they will offer but won't say that they'll charge you. -Prices are not shown when handed the dessert menu. What we had was great. When we received the bill, they were €22 each. Overall, if you want to experience outstanding service (which is very very important to us), I would suggest to try this place. Be warned that it will cost you average €150 per person! Compared to other Michelin star rated restaurants we've been to, I would say this wouldn't top the list on value. I believe there should be a balance of artistic qualities and portion served. After-all, food is still consumed to feed our hunger!

review_preview: Two different friends who grew near this legendary seafood bar / restaurant near Retiro park highly recommended this place to have some wines and some nice tapas, and we weren't disappointed in the least.When we arrived at 8:30, the bar area, which is rather...
review_full: Two different friends who grew near this legendary seafood bar / restaurant near Retiro park highly recommended this place to have some wines and some nice tapas, and we weren't disappointed in the least. When we arrived at 8:30, the bar area, which is rather small, was 3/4 full and teeming with energy. The crowd was a mix of middle aged couples and older folk, well dressed but not overly dressed, completely enjoying themselves. We ordered the house Rioja and the house Somotano red for 2.20€. Both were excellent young wines that were served with a tapa of cooked shrimp with some snails. Fantastic! The next round we tried the Ribera del Duero, which was also quite tasty, same price, and served with croquettes of béchamel and trufa. Delicious pairing! The service was very attentive and friendly. I would definitely go back, but probably during the week, not on Friday or Saturday because of the crowd. Another place right down the street that I would highly recommend as well is El Capricho.

The food was simply delicious! The menu was varied! Lots of different types of fish were available on the day! I chose rise with octopus half portion, fillet steak that was melting in my mouth and by the time I ate these, I couldn't breathe! I desperately wanted to try the dessert with Forrest fruits, but I really had no space in my stomach! So this was the only disappointment! I will definitely go back and certainly recommend!!! Oh and the service was great! Friendly! Accommodating! Very very good! Excellent!

review_preview: This place was packed on a Friday night.  There was actually another table from the US, so the word is definitely out there that this place is a true treasure.  The restaurant is located near the Ibiza Metro station, very close to the neighborhood I...
review_full: This place was packed on a Friday night. There was actually another table from the US, so the word is definitely out there that this place is a true treasure. The restaurant is located near the Ibiza Metro station, very close to the neighborhood I lived in when I studied abroad in Madrid. The area was hopping during the first weekend in September, as vacation has ended in Madrid. We started with the mushrooms and clams and shared the sirloin for dinner. We couldn't remember enjoying a steak cooked as well as it was done here (medium rare) in a very long time. There was a Spanish actor enjoying dinner with friends at a table near us - the waiter told us. So obviously this place is a hidden gem for tourists, but very well-known to the locals. We shared a bottle of their house wine which was 14 euros. It was a lovely last evening at La Castela for us.

review_full: If you visit one tapas bar in Madrid, then go to La Castela. Its a bit of a trek from the city centre, but well worth it. We walked from Plaza Mayor, through Retiro Park, and worked up a good thirst! Each drink comes with a tapa, and they are definitely a cut above the norm. We also had the recommended oxtail stew and fillet steak with foie. 2 beers and 2 glasses of wine and the total bill was Euro 38! By far the best food that we had during our visit, and the cheapest. Cant wait to go back.

Service is very nice and truly friendly (something difficult to find in Madrid); the bar tender seems to enjoy so much his job, that you will think he hates vacations. The ambiance is Madrid at its best: noisy, crowded, démodé decoration, with people struggling to find a small corner to eat, but full of joy while eating, drinking and laughing with friends ... this is Madrid as you expect it to be....

review_preview: A nice little bar with a great restaurant attached.  As others have said, its a local neighbourhood kind of place. The bar is bustling, noisy, and full of people enjoying the delicious tapas and cooling canas of beer.  But for the real deal head, struggle...
review_full: A nice little bar with a great restaurant attached. As others have said, its a local neighbourhood kind of place. The bar is bustling, noisy, and full of people enjoying the delicious tapas and cooling canas of beer.  But for the real deal head, struggle past the punters pressed against the left hand wall and go through the door to the back where a cosy, intimate and unashamedly old-fashioned restaurant serves top quality food at remarkably fair prices. Especially notable? The zabarinos (baby scallops); chick peas with prawn (more delicious and succulent than can possibly be done justice to in this review; the grilled turbot (rodaballo) ..in fact all the fish dishes are excellent. Be sure to try one or two of the desserts - the apple tart with ice cream is amazing - wafer thin with a lightly crispy base and an intense apple-iness that is irresistible.  Service is old school Spanish - very proper, very professional. somebody describes it here as "self-important" - I understand what the reviewer is saying but I think the main waiter just takes a pride in the great job that he does. And he does. Once you've finished eating, you'll never be rushed out of your seat - if you fancy staying for a nice long G&T you'll be able to relax and enjoy your digestivo. Perfect way to round off a splendid meal, IMHO.  Oh...and don't forget to book. La Castela is ALWAYS full - testament to its enduring quality and value.

review_preview: I'm going to start with a negative, because this otherwise solid restaurant hit one of my pet peeves - despite spending hundreds of Euros on a meal, I was charged a quite hefty fee for...bread!  I love fine dining, and I will spend a pretty...
review_full: I'm going to start with a negative, because this otherwise solid restaurant hit one of my pet peeves - despite spending hundreds of Euros on a meal, I was charged a quite hefty fee for...bread! I love fine dining, and I will spend a pretty penny for a good meal, but a fine restaurant should never nickel and dime. Well, enough about that, other than to emphasize that this place is quite pricey. On to the good - the service is impeccable, the atmosphere quite perfect (neither too fancy or too casual), and the food is overall quite good. Unfortunately, while the main course meat dish was the highlight, most of the other courses were far-outshined by the delicious amuse bouche offerings. The cheese course and wine were also stand-outs. We ordered the set menu, so we were stuffed. Fortunately, being Americans, the first lunch seating 2pm allowed us to linger to 5pm and not worry about dinner. I'd definitely go again, but I wonder if this restaurant might have peaked.

review_preview: It's taken a full month for the Docent to fully process our experience at Santceloni.  Granted, we dined there on New Year's Eve and most restaurants do fail to meet expectations on such highly anticipated occasions.  But, the food was absolutely superb. What was troubling...
review_full: It's taken a full month for the Docent to fully process our experience at Santceloni. Granted, we dined there on New Year's Eve and most restaurants do fail to meet expectations on such highly anticipated occasions. But, the food was absolutely superb. What was troubling was the curious service that book-ended this most incredible meal. Perhaps the first problem was in part our fault. We entered the Hesperia Hotel to gain entry. After a bit of kerfuffle at the maitre d' stand, we were escorted by a waiter (who, by the way, was just as confused as we were) into an elevator and down to what could only be described as the basement. A musty funk brushed our faces as the elevator doors opened onto an unlit room scattered with furniture. We were polite, but the waiter spoke up. "What is THIS?," he snarled as we groped our way toward the light. Out of the mist a hostess emerged and took over our tour. Civilization, at last!  The New Year's Eve tasting menu was really quite good. And the service was swift and efficient. Too swift. So swift we felt as if we were getting the bum's rush, especially after we had had our 12 grapes at midnight and paid our bill. Amazingly, we were hurriedly ushered up a heretofore unseen flight of stairs that led to street, entirely bypassing the Hesperia Hotel.  What was that all about? I guess, we'll never know.

review_preview: We cannot comment the food served by La Castela, not having been given the opportunity tosample it. What we can give feedback on is our experience of the quality of La Castela’s customer service, and specifically its professionalism faced with its error over our booking(see...
review_full: We cannot comment the food served by La Castela, not having been given the opportunity tosample it. What we can give feedback on is our experience of the quality of La Castela’s customer service, and specifically its professionalism faced with its error over our booking(see the backstory below) – of which inadequate, complacent, and the perhaps the worstexperience we have had with any restaurant in 25 years of international travel, is an entirelyaccurate review! In February we book a table for two people for dinner at 21:00 CET on Friday 18 March2016, as part of our planned holiday in Spain. On Monday 15 February we received an emailconfirmation of this booking from La Castela. At 16.54 CET on the day of our booking, Friday 18 March 2016, we received an email reminder and further confirmation of our booking from La Castela. We hurried back to Madrid from a day in Toledo, hungry and looking forward to a relaxingand leisurely dinner, and arrived at La Castela at 20:50 CET on Friday 18 March. On arrivalwe were first told that the restaurant had no record of our booking! Mistakes happen, and the measure of any good restaurant is how it recovers when faced with its mistake. In this instance La Castela was found entirely wanting. The senior waiter was dismissive, and quickly returned to eating his own dinner having not given our problem more than cursory attention. Another younger waiter then tried to help. Ultimately he found a booking for us on “Tuesday”, not the day or date on the confirmation we had produced asevidence of our booking for 18 March. And what did La Castela offer us; a table if we could finish our meal in an hour and vacate it by 10pm!? We declined this entirely unsatisfactory offer. As if to add insult to injury, at 21:02 CET on Saturday 19 March 2016 we received aninvitation from La Castela to provide a review of our experience on the preceding day translated from Spanish: 'We hope you enjoyed your visit to La Castela. It is very important for us to have the opinion of our customers. We are grateful to you very much for taking a moment and complete this brief survey. Thank you very much.'!!!!!

title_review: Showing up some basic but excellent Spanish traditional dishes
review_preview: We had a couple of friends visiting from London this week. They are from The Netherlands and enjoy in particular good raw materials, specially seafood, shell fish and vegetables. I selected La Castela following friends advice as well as it was chosen for Michelle Obama...
review_full: We had a couple of friends visiting from London this week. They are from The Netherlands and enjoy in particular good raw materials, specially seafood, shell fish and vegetables. I selected La Castela following friends advice as well as it was chosen for Michelle Obama when she was in Spain in the summer of 2016.  And it was fantastic: it was just simple, well served, fresh and delicious food. We had razor shells, squid with onion and Tuna salad for starters. The tomato was astonishing as a very basic food but that can be boring and neutral taste. The shells were tasty and perfectly grilled and squid as soft and juicy as it can be. We then moved into a variety of monkfish, hake, turbot and lamb chops with salad and roasted potatoes as company. And ended with three deserts to share: rice pudding, apple pie and meillefoille with cream. Water and some white wine of Rueda.  We didn't fill heavy but pleased. Service was implacable and price to quality more than fine. Yes. We will definitely come back here and I absolutely recommend this if you want to taste a full and diverse range of the best food in Spain.

review_preview: What could I say about this restaurant? Every time, while visiting a new cities, besides the historical and architectural attractions, we always try to have a good food experience. This time, during our trip to Madrid, we went to the Santceloni Restaurant. It was not...
review_full: What could I say about this restaurant?  Every time, while visiting a new cities, besides the historical and architectural attractions, we always try to have a good food experience.  This time, during our trip to Madrid, we went to the Santceloni Restaurant. It was not voluntary choice, our hotel's concierge made us a reservation (so no Trip-advising before). However we knew that our dinner should be delicious, especially because it has been awarded 2 michelin stars. The Restaurant itself is very beautiful. All of us, we were charmed by it's deco, the choice of colors, furniture, etc. We were also welcomed warmly and during the whole meal the service was attentive to our needs and always ready to answer our questions. However at the end we had a slight problem with an unexperienced waiter, who instead of bringing us the right desserts (we actually pointed them in the menu!!), twice got us different sorbet flavors instead of wanted positions.  We decided to order "a la carte", so we tried different starters, fish plates, cheeses and desserts. Savory dishes were good, but they were not exceptional or very elevated. Peace of fish (of course I realize that it has the best quality) with a peace of carrot, morel mushroom or a foam. I actually expected more. Nevertheless the sweet part was amazing!! I saw a lot of obligatory setting up at the dessert section and so many different taste combinations. It was hard to choose, but each of us was happy with his plate and unwilling to share even a bite with the others.  I also would like to talk about their Sommelier. Sometimes, in the different restaurants the wine waiters seem to be very serious and snobby, creating kind off unpleasant atmosphere, but this guy here, not only suggested us a perfect wine, but also was ready to chit chat a little about his profession and place itself.  To sum up. I have to admit, that I saw "more" creativity on my plate in the small bistros than in this two star restaurant, but I also agree, that it is still a very nice place to go and have a good meal with your family or friends.

review_preview: This is what Spanish food should be! 4 of us had 4 appetizers and 2 main courses, 2 bottles of wine; a Cava, and a 2008 Malleolus tinto fino. Everything was as good as food can get! A complementary starter of grilled sardines on toast,...
review_full: This is what Spanish food should be! 4 of us had 4 appetizers and 2 main courses, 2 bottles of wine; a Cava, and a 2008 Malleolus tinto fino. Everything was as good as food can get! A complementary starter of grilled sardines on toast, a vertical salad of tuna and peppers, hake and eggs like silk, grilled asparagus with house made mayonnaise, clams with jamon iberico and chives in sherry, a perfectly grilled turbot, and the best solomillo w/ foie gras ever! two brilliant deserts- a rice pudding with mango, and a warm chocolate nut cake with sweet cream ice cream. We were full , and incredibly happy. The price was so reasonable, that we booked a table for tomorrow night, as we are confident that a better meal can't be found anywhere near the price. The service was impeccable, and we felt so welcomed from the moment we sat down.

review_preview: We were a group of eight lucky enough to be pointed to this gem by a Madrilena friend.  Front of house is a tapas bar featuring the freshest seafood, which was very busy with local business people at lunchtime.  We started with a glass of...
review_full: We were a group of eight lucky enough to be pointed to this gem by a Madrilena friend. Front of house is a tapas bar featuring the freshest seafood, which was very busy with local business people at lunchtime. We started with a glass of wine or beer which was accompanied by free dishes of fresh shell-on prawns before being shown to the table we had booked in the dining room at the back. Formal tables, white linen cloths and napkins but the waiters couldn't have been more accommodating when we decided to have a selection of tapas rather than a formal meal. Tapas were brought in groups of two or three dishes, brought swiftly but timed to arrive just as we came to finishing the previous selection. Each tapa was freshly cooked and delicious and the suggested wines were perfect companions. And if you still have enough room, do try the rice pudding! Not cheap but if you're looking for a taste of first class Spanish cuisine, this place can't be beaten for food, service and ambience.

title_review: Children not welcome - EVEN ON NEW YEARS EVE!
review_preview: I write to share my disappointment about the policies at this restaurant. I will spending New Years Eve in Madrid with all my family. Being originally from Spain, and having been to the restaurant before during a business lunch, I decided to organize our dinner...
review_full: I write to share my disappointment about the policies at this restaurant.  I will spending New Years Eve in Madrid with all my family. Being originally from Spain, and having been to the restaurant before during a business lunch, I decided to organize our dinner plans for that date at the wonderful restaurant at the Hesperia Hotel. We are a party of five adults, one 4-year old and one 1-year old. Given that we frequently visit highly rated restaurants and, therefore, know that different businesses have different policies, I carefully checked the terms on SantCeloni's website. Nothing seemed to indicate that children were not allowed or welcomed. In fact, this being the restaurant at a prestigious hotel in Madrid (and given the special date –New Years Eve), I simply assumed that, in light of the warmness culture of the Spanish, it was probably appropriate to bring my kids (otherwise well-behaved and little gourmands themselves).  I made my reservation through their website, making it clear that I had some children in my party. I tried to make it as soon as possible (8:00 p.m. or so), although only 22:30 p.m. was available. With much embarrassment, I immediately received a phone call letting me know that "although children are not specifically prohibited, they are not welcomed in the restaurant" "they generally would not enjoy the experience" and they offered a baby sitter during dinner.  I thought this was completely disappointing from a client point of view: 1) this is New Years Eve (a family gathering from a Spanish cultural point of view), 2) considering the numbers at our party, we thought they would make every effort to welcome us (perhaps by suggesting a separate area from the main dining room? –they do have such possibility), 3) we believe our kids have the same right to enjoy good food as adults have and teaching them how to do so at an early age is extremely important (was the alternative to feed them with pizza and leave them with an unknown baby sitter during the last day of the year???). Having been with my kids to numerous Michelin rated restaurants (including Sergi Arola's –whose brother personally cooked a tremendous seabass croquette for my son!) all over the world (and run by much more reputable/known names than chef Oscar Velasco), I can only say that this is not how a business should be run: the client (and his demands) should always be put first. Otherwise, it should be clearly stated on their website to avoid disappointment. I strongly recommend not going to this restaurant. A culinary experience should be one that meets all of the client's expectations, including having a clear sense on rules and, of course, trying to please the client.

title_review: incredible but pricey - seasonal tasting menu is superb
review_preview: Food & service were impeccable. Prices are commensurate with a 2 star restaurant. If you take the grand tasting menu with the wine pairing (which we did) you will spend 240 Euros per person.You can order one of the 2 tasting menus or a...
review_full: Food & service were impeccable. Prices are commensurate with a 2 star restaurant. If you take the grand tasting menu with the wine pairing (which we did) you will spend 240 Euros per person. You can order one of the 2 tasting menus or a la carte. The tasting menus are developed based on what is fresh and what your likes and dislikes are. We had the grand tasting menu and my wife & I thought it was superb. We saw something on the regular menu that intrigued us so we asked if it could be included and they obliged with no problem. You'll also get a long string of pre-appetizers, each very unique and exquisite in taste. Everything was seasoned perfectly. The one caveat is that despite the individual portions not being that large, 6 courses plus the various extras is simply too much food and if you eat all of it you will regret it. Similarly, we had the wine pairing which was excellent, however it was far too much alcohol. I strongly advise not finishing all of it unless you are comfortable polishing off an entire bottle of wine per person. The room and decor were quite nice. The room is large, the tables are well spaced, and there is a step up from the lower central area to the outer seating area which breaks up the space nicely. Highly recommended if you have the money and like this sort of thing.

review_preview: One of the nicest things about Madrid is the Tapas Bar - and there are hundreds of them !   They are unique to Spain and slot in nicely with the Spanish lifestyle.   Clearly, some will be better than others and Taberna Laredo  certainly falls in...
review_full: One of the nicest things about Madrid is the Tapas Bar - and there are hundreds of them ! They are unique to Spain and slot in nicely with the Spanish lifestyle. Clearly, some will be better than others and Taberna Laredo certainly falls in the 'better' variety. Not only very typical (and very busy) but good value with excellent choices of Tapas from which to select your preferences. I can sit happily for a couple of hours (or more) drinking good quality Spanish wines and eating a variety of foods - all of them both attractively served and very tasty. If you wish to eat 'Restaurant Style' you can do so - upstairs. But if you wish to do so then make sure you have a reservation - absolutely essential. Highly recommended.

review_preview: We enjoyed our dinner at La Castela and would recommend this restaurant. It is located in a residential side street just off a main road and is about 8 mins walk from the Goya metro station. The neighbourhood is quiet at night but we felt...
review_full: We enjoyed our dinner at La Castela and would recommend this restaurant. It is located in a residential side street just off a main road and is about 8 mins walk from the Goya metro station. The neighbourhood is quiet at night but we felt safe. On a Monday night, both the tapas bar in the front and the restaurant at the back were full - so reservation is necessary. English menus.  The serving staffs speak fluent English and were helpful. We did not like the small table at the back of the dining room they gave the two of us (we had reservation) and they swiftly gave us a larger table in the main dining area. We also asked to change an appetiser after seeing what other tables were having (a tuna tomato salad) and they quickly checked if the kitchen had already prepared what we had originally ordered. Decor of the dining room is classic but not dated. The dining room is small but we did not feel cramped.  The restaurant serves traditional Spanish cuisine. The food were well executed and not too salty. In addition to the tuna tomato salad, we enjoyed both the pork and the octopus rice dish. Dinner for two with two appetisers, two main courses, one desert and one cava cost E93.

review_preview: On the recommendation of a friend, we got a reservation at La Castela for our first night in Spain.  It turned out to be our best meal of the trip.The food was outstanding.  We started with the jamon, which was everything we were hoping...
review_full: On the recommendation of a friend, we got a reservation at La Castela for our first night in Spain. It turned out to be our best meal of the trip. The food was outstanding. We started with the jamon, which was everything we were hoping for, and moved on to seafood for our mains. Both my wife's langoustine dish and my rice with octopus and squid were perfectly cooked--the creaminess of my rice contrasted nicely with the firmness of the octopus and squid.  Even better than the food was the service. Our waiter timed everything perfectly and was conscientious of every issue. He did an fantastic job throughout the evening. The dining room is small, so reservations are probably needed. And the next time I'm in Madrid, I'll definitely go back.

We ate, amongst the 3 of us, various fish plates and 1 bottle of Verdejo wine, a glass of Baileys and a glass of red wine (Vino Tinto.) Restaurant was nearly full but not jam packed, quite good for a Monday! Service was a tad slow and some of the waiters spoke English. Cost came to 140.03 Euros including I.V.A.(rip off tax), would go back but not right away. Crowd jams the bar area but then things thin out as you get in to the dining rooms. Met some folks visiting from Chicago, hurray for them for venturing off the beaten path!

There's a tasty guacamole "salad" plate that we often share as a starter (it's smoother than my own, and I prefer chunky guac, but the flavors are always spot on). with tacos (shells made by hand and great!) or burritos or whatever your pleasure, you've a choice of half a dozen proteins (I love both the cochinita pibil and the quite rich chicken with mole) great variety of tequilas, nice margaritas and cold beer. It's asimple, welcoming place with good portions and pricing!

title_review: Best Mexican food outside of Mexico
review_preview: The Spanish/Mexican couple who own this restaurant have it figured out. Offer the best homemade food from Mexico, pair it with great drinks, in a cozy atmosphere, with good music and friendly service. I had enchiladas verde - the kind of spice I've been dreaming...
review_full: The Spanish/Mexican couple who own this restaurant have it figured out. Offer the best homemade food from Mexico, pair it with great drinks, in a cozy atmosphere, with good music and friendly service.  I had enchiladas verde - the kind of spice I've been dreaming of for months! My husband had just about every kind of taco on the menu. And we topped it off with nachos and Pacifico beers. Everything is homemade, and it shows. The restaurant is cute and would be great for dinner as well. There was a bigger dining area in back for larger parties.  We come to Madrid often, and this will now be one of our regular stops.

review_preview: This is by far the best Mexican food in Madrid! It's in Madrid Centro, but a little removed and on the corner of a side street, about 2 or 3 blocks from Gran Via. It's worth finding. Don't get it confused with the restaurant La...
review_full: This is by far the best Mexican food in Madrid! It's in Madrid Centro, but a little removed and on the corner of a side street, about 2 or 3 blocks from Gran Via. It's worth finding. Don't get it confused with the restaurant La Veganza de Malinche. This one -- La Malinche -- is much, MUCH better! The food is fully homemade, and you can taste it. Very authentic, with full, hearty meals at a good price. And if you want picante, you can get picante! It's nice because they don't drown the food in cheese, so you can really taste the flavors. The atmosphere is simple and cozy but elegant, which is a nice change from the other candy-colored Mexican places. The staff is very friendly, helpful, and attentive. Eat here!

title_review: Exquisite food totally let down by the appalling 'service'
review_preview: We visited Laredo for lunch (the upstairs restaurant)  in February 2013.  We arrived dead on time at 2 pm and were rudely asked to go back down the stairs  because 'we aren't ready'. We meekly obliged and then got called back up. We were seated...
review_full: We visited Laredo for lunch (the upstairs restaurant) in February 2013. We arrived dead on time at 2 pm and were rudely asked to go back down the stairs because 'we aren't ready'. We meekly obliged and then got called back up. We were seated in the right hand corner next to a window. So far so good. We were then studiously ignored by the two young madams who were masquerading as 'waiters' for about 25 minutes. We finally got a menu. then, after some time, some bread arrived. Meanwhile two 'suits' next to us were well into their main course (of a hearty five course lunch - we had plenty of time to observe and count).  We checked the underside of our shoes to see if there was any 'doggy do' which was keeping the staff away from us. No, all clear. We have no idea what the problem was. It just seemed incredibly rude and incompetent. Finally our orders were taken and our food arrived. But, where was the water and drinks? We waited while the food became cold. In desperation, one of us went downstairs to retrieve the floor 'manager' and to get some wine. We were very tempted to walk out. We are glad we stayed, because the food was exquisite. We enjoyed the food immensely, but the service was so awful, we couldn't wait to get out. With Spain's unemployment reaching record highs, surely the management of this restaurant could find some capable and willing waiters?? An awful experience. Never again.

title_review: Heavenly tapas!! But oh, the crowd...
review_preview: Taberna Laredo was recently renewed and passed from a typical, old fashioned to a super cosmopolitan spot. The best was kept exactly the same, though: the food. We had revuelto de morcilla (scrambled eggs with a typical Spanish sausage that has some rice in the...
review_full: Taberna Laredo was recently renewed and passed from a typical, old fashioned to a super cosmopolitan spot. The best was kept exactly the same, though: the food. We had revuelto de morcilla (scrambled eggs with a typical Spanish sausage that has some rice in the filling) and a vegetable tempura. Both were the best examples of the respective dish. The down side is the typical disadvantages of going out for dinner in Madrid without a reservation: the place is always crowded, you have to be lucky enough to find a small corner on the bar, and eat standing with a fork and a napkin on your hand. It seemed like it was also possible to book a table, but the menu appeared to be different. Despite of the noise and the crowd, it is definitely worth it to visit Laredo. Be prepared for waiting for a spot and your food - just have a glass of wine while you're doing so - and to pay above-average for some delicious tapas.

review_full: It was our first day in Madrid and we were looking for restaurants nearby. We noticed modern looking pictures of this restaurant and wanted to give it a try. It was turned to be one of our best restaurant experience in Madrid. When you go in through the door located on main street, it looks like a very nice bar serving food, yoksa know “bar food”. But when you look at the faces, you can feel how happy they are with the food they are being served.  Then they took us to the restaurant part, the looks of it, well ı would never go inside. But when they started to serve food, you can understand why this restaurant is so popular among local people. We had prawns ( on the house) grilled squid, clam in a sauce and asparagus and they were perfect. The sauce of the clam and aspragus were so good, I had to stop my daughter using then as a dip sauce and asking for extra bread. We paid 55 euros for the food and a glass of wine

We shared the cauliflower and roasted pear with goat cheese tapas. Their tapas change regularly, but these were both very good. I ordered a shandy to drink which was refreshing but beware, less than 1% of alcohol haha! Each humus comes with 2 slices of pita bread also. Large portions at a great price. Will be back!

title_review: Excellent food for a special occassion
review_preview: Went to the restaurant for our anniversary, and found it to be excellent value for money as a double Michelin star restaurant. The wife and I ordered one main course and one dessert each, but with all the free extras, we must have had about...
review_full: Went to the restaurant for our anniversary, and found it to be excellent value for money as a double Michelin star restaurant. The wife and I ordered one main course and one dessert each, but with all the free extras, we must have had about 16 different dishes in the end! Each and every dish was a real experience for the palette ... may struggle to beat this experience in future anniversaries!! We didn't try the cheese or the bread, as we were completely full with just our main food - but both the selection, and the service, was exemplary. And they gave us a lovely gift on our special day, a lovely little plant to bring back home. Thanks!

review_preview: Went to Santceloni and while the price is steep, this restaurant is one of the best I have ever been to. The chef's tasting courses were a delight, and the menu had lighter options than most of the other restaurants we visited in Spain. The...
review_full: Went to Santceloni and while the price is steep, this restaurant is one of the best I have ever been to. The chef's tasting courses were a delight, and the menu had lighter options than most of the other restaurants we visited in Spain. The Squid noodle and Pea puree was delicious, and available on the tasting menu or ala carte. My wife and I both had Fish entrees, and the wine list was excellent and one of the more economical areas of the menu. A must to go to in Madrid, and reservations are a must, as far in advance as possible. Its a little bit hard to find the entrance/address on foot as it’s in the ground floor of a hotel.

review_preview: We had visited Santi Santamaria's El Raco con Fabes years ago.  When he opened in Madrid, we were pleased to see the great reviews.  His excellence lives on here.  There are rustic touches in the elegant and modern dining room reminiscent of Con Fabes that...
review_full: We had visited Santi Santamaria's El Raco con Fabes years ago. When he opened in Madrid, we were pleased to see the great reviews. His excellence lives on here. There are rustic touches in the elegant and modern dining room reminiscent of Con Fabes that provide a nice juxtaposition to the glass and steel and iron foundational elements and the central and imposing colossal sculpture that dominates the main dining area. The service is top drawer- friendly, helpful, attentive, but not intrusive or cloying. In a word, perfect. The cuisine is modern and tres a la mode- explosions of flavor and unexpected constructs and forms. It is just plain fun to give yourself over to the chef de cuisine and the sommelier and let them make you dinner of their choosing with wine pairings that perfectly match the food. A great deal of the fun (and dining here is meant to be fun as there was much laughter and joy coming from many tables) was created by the sommelier who was so enthusiastic about his choices and expressive in his descriptions of the wines put before us. Indeed, this is an enthusiastic place- for your comfort, enjoyment and relaxation. It is one of the better experiences we have had- and we have been to most of the Michelin trios etoiles places in Paris and Burgundy. But don't take our word for it- go and have fun for yourself.

title_review: Local unpretentious eatery serving authentic, delicious Spanish food.
review_preview: Thanks to the Michelin Guide for enticing us (via their Bib Gourmand) accreditation to eat here.  The restaurant is in a pleasant local neighborhood near the Park Retiro.   The food is bistro-style, not fancy, but very well prepared and really delicious.  After a complimentary plate...
review_full: Thanks to the Michelin Guide for enticing us (via their Bib Gourmand) accreditation to eat here.  The restaurant is in a pleasant local neighborhood near the Park Retiro. The food is bistro-style, not fancy, but very well prepared and really delicious. After a complimentary plate of fresh, sweet shrimp (washed down by chilled Manzanilla sherry), we sampled the excellent appetizer of layered tuna and pepper salad. Then we went on to baked hake and grilled turbot -- both perfectly cooked. Naturally fish must swim, so we ordered a bottle of San Coldio Ribeiro -- well priced at 15 euros/btl. Dessert was a delicious mint semifredo with red berries (sublime). Two Orujos (Galician grappa-equivalent) arrived on the house and ended a most enjoyable meal.

title_review: Very good food, attentaative service, large portions
review_preview: Came here as group of six on Saturday evening. Restaurant is split in half, Tapas bar in front and sit-down restaurant at back. You've to walk past the bar to get to the restaurant.Restaurant is run by well-organised team, who execute a fast and...
review_full: Came here as group of six on Saturday evening. Restaurant is split in half, Tapas bar in front and sit-down restaurant at back. You've to walk past the bar to get to the restaurant. Restaurant is run by well-organised team, who execute a fast and attentative service. Food was excellent throughout, be it the Madrid classics or the "normal" dishes. It is quite heavy on meat and fish, for vegetarians there is limited choice. There is a small choice of open wines and wines by the bottle, all very sensibly priced. If there is one critisism it is the portion size, they are all large. For my taste I would've expecially liked the starters to be smallers. A definitive recommendation.

review_preview: Visited with a group of 3 friends for dinner and arrived exactly at 8:30 when it opened so we got a great table on the upper level. Within 15 minutes the restaurant was full, so I recommend arriving early. Among the 4 of us we...
review_full: Visited with a group of 3 friends for dinner and arrived exactly at 8:30 when it opened so we got a great table on the upper level. Within 15 minutes the restaurant was full, so I recommend arriving early. Among the 4 of us we had two orders of hummus, a tapa and a salad which was the perfect amount, leaving us all full and happy and paying less than 7 euros each. The sweet potato tapa was wonderful and I would absolutely order the ensalada primavera again which was made with mango and dates. The server was helpful and able to substitute some of our pitas for a gluten free version for no extra charge. I was looking for a restaurant that was a change from the typical greasy tapas that are common in Madrid and this place hit the spot. It was the best meal I've had in the city due to the fresh and wholesome menu items and the warm, artful interior.

review_preview: I visited this place earlier this week, as part of a business visit to our Madrid colleagues. They took us here and we were all sincerely pleased with the ambience, atmosphere, warmth, quality of food, quality of drinks and outstanding service at this place. Usually...
review_full: I visited this place earlier this week, as part of a business visit to our Madrid colleagues. They took us here and we were all sincerely pleased with the ambience, atmosphere, warmth, quality of food, quality of drinks and outstanding service at this place.  Usually I divide my reviews in pros and cons, but this place has no cons.  When you arrive there is a bar type of area, where people are having tapas, mostly standing. Very busy, but with good atmosphere. Tapas and entrees are really amazing. I'm pesquerarian so I couldn't try the jamon serrano but that looked really amazing and my colleagues loved it. The bread was also good, and the cheese was so tasty.  You will see lots of napkins in the floor! They say that the good tapas places in Spain are those were there are napkins there, so this one must be considered amongst them ;-) Once you are done with step one of the night, which is the tapas and drinks in that bar entry area, you may choose to go inside through a small door, where there have a proper restaurant, with spacious seating.  We ordered a lot of food to share. I had the rice with octopus and squid and it was simply delicious. Also I tried the lenguado some of my colleagues ordered and I found it awesome. Also the veggies with fried eggs were good, and overall everything I tried I found exceptional.  Wine was very good too! Next time I go back to Madrid I definitely want to visit again!

title_review: A wonderful evening...shame about the sommelier!
review_preview: The restaurant has a lovely atmosphere as soon as you enter and the waiter Jorge was welcoming and full of smiles unlike some other Michelin star restaurants where everything can be too serious. The food was fantastic! One course wasn't exactly to our liking but...
review_full: The restaurant has a lovely atmosphere as soon as you enter and the waiter Jorge was welcoming and full of smiles unlike some other Michelin star restaurants where everything can be too serious. The food was fantastic! One course wasn't exactly to our liking but was whisked away and replaced with something totally delicious almost seamlessly. The cheese selection is to die for!! It is displayed on a huge wooden table.  The only complaint we had was the sommelier. We didn't go for the wine pairing but I asked for a recommendation for a glass of red wine to accompany the cheeses. The sommelier never smiled, took an already poured glass over without discussing any options with me beforehand, told me nothing about it, didn't stay to see if I liked it (which in fact I didn't really) and off he went. That was a real negative point for such an expensive, highly rated restaurant. I think he assumed we didn't care or knew nothing of wine which was not the case. A real shame. For that reason I probably wouldn't go back although the food was excellent.

title_review: Pay a lot for terrible food
review_preview: This place should have been a no-brainer, as it has 2 Michelin stars. Evidently those mean nothing because I can tell you that every course except dessert made me gag. I started off with smoked mackerel that was chewy and could not have possibly been...
review_full: This place should have been a no-brainer, as it has 2 Michelin stars. Evidently those mean nothing because I can tell you that every course except dessert made me gag. I started off with smoked mackerel that was chewy and could not have possibly been fresh. I spent the rest of the evening with a napkin stuffed with half-chewed mackerel in my suit jacket pocket. My main was sea bream which was also awful. I don't think it was fresh and the brown muscle was overbearing, possibly rancid and permeated the whole fish. I also got the tail end, which is the cheapest cut. Worse, it probably cost 50-60 euros. My wife didn't have as rough a time as I did but I asked her to rate her meal and she gave it a 4 out of 10. For these prices you should expect much more. Look, I can't explain the other positive reviews here but coming from New York City, and having eaten at other Michelin star restaurants here, this place was severely disappointing and probably the worst meal I had in two full weeks in various places across Spain. But forget Michelin restaurants in NYC where you can basically know you're going to eat well for the price like Del Posto, Babbo and many others: you can eat better than Santceloni anywhere where they have pride in the freshness of the food they serve. I routinely have better meals at home without having to pay $450 for it. Maybe you'll have a better experience than we did. Many people seem to enjoy this place. I will just tell you that the food was basically inedible.

review_preview: Went with my wife there for lunch on a weekday.Arrived at around 1pm, the Tapas bar was quite full of people but the dining room inside was not opened yet. In the midst of a crowd we managed to get a table with two...
review_full: Went with my wife there for lunch on a weekday. Arrived at around 1pm, the Tapas bar was quite full of people but the dining room inside was not opened yet. In the midst of a crowd we managed to get a table with two high chairs. The bar tender was very polite and helpful. Lots of seafood there - we ordered a few Tapas and the bar tender asked if we would like to have the "cabarineros" - the Spanish giant scarlet prawns. Lucky we ordered them - so delicious! If you are not a Spanish you don't have much chance to taste it and it must be more expensive outside Spain.  All the Tapas we ordered were presented elegantly and they were very delicious. A man next to our table asked my wife to come over and share his Tapas - some fried small clams which he said was unique in Spain. We started chatting and I guess this is the Spanish way of meeting people in Tapas bars. The atmosphere of the bar was excellent. The food was elegant. The price was reasonable. And it was not difficult to find - nearest metro is Ibiza. Very satisfied, and highly recommended!

Not enough to put me off planning my next trip to Madrid, primarily to go back to this place again.

review_preview: We chose this restaurant for lunch without any previous recommendations nor knowledge, as we like Portuguese food and have frequently travelled to Portugal and Brazil, where we had very good codfish, tasty and with generous portions. Maybe a choice too quickly made after seeing this...
review_full: We chose this restaurant for lunch without any previous recommendations nor knowledge, as we like Portuguese food and have frequently travelled to Portugal and Brazil, where we had very good codfish, tasty and with generous portions. Maybe a choice too quickly made after seeing this restaurant in Google and being in the area. When entering it becomes apparent that this is a place (even though located in a relatively new neighborhood of Madrid) that emulates traditional Portuguese restaurants like the ones you can find in Lisbon: traditional tiles (or imitations thereof, as the restaurant is not that old) on the walls; Portuguese paintings; dark wood; several plates, glasses and heavy tablecloth already on the table. Then you see an army of waiters; too many for the number of guests present. It reminded me overstaffed Brazilian restaurants, where most of the time the waiters were…waiting. As for the food, our impressions were mixed: the small starters and cod (bacalao) carpaccio was good; the bread was fresh; the cod (yes, this is a place that specializes in cod) with seafood rather mediocre: tasteless, not a little bit salty, not a little bit hot, nor the prawns tasting very fresh), and the uniform brown color of all its ingredients did not help either. The waiters did not seem to be in a good mood: we received short answers to our questions, no small talk or smile. In general, the food quality, quantity and overall experience was poor for what we paid (prepare 30-50 Euros per person).

title_review: Pleasingly calm, polite service and delicious food
review_preview: I came here for a dinner during a business trip and without having a booking. There were plenty of tables available and I was quickly seated in a nice place, with lots of space and generally calm and relaxing atmosphere.The menu is a simple...
review_full: I came here for a dinner during a business trip and without having a booking. There were plenty of tables available and I was quickly seated in a nice place, with lots of space and generally calm and relaxing atmosphere. The menu is a simple one with interesting fish and meat proposals. I went for a pincho-like starter combining mackerel with avocado and mango and it was quite a gourmet experience. The main course of medium-rare sirloin steak was also flawless and totally delicious. In terms of wine list the proposal are pretty good and especially when it come to white wines, there are some good finds at proper prices. What I also liked was the kind and attentive service. Friendly (and not intimidating) , they were coming at right moments to ask me questions or to take care of my meals. In conclusion, if you find yourself in the area, this is most definitely a place to recommend for a dinner!

title_review: Excellent dinner for us here in Madrid for a tradeshow
review_preview: We are here in Madrid for a tradeshow and wanted to find a yummy place for our team dinner. We made an (early) reservation for 8 pm knowing that most restaurants don't open till 9:00 pm. The entire staff was so accommodating realizing that we...
review_full: We are here in Madrid for a tradeshow and wanted to find a yummy place for our team dinner. We made an (early) reservation for 8 pm knowing that most restaurants don't open till 9:00 pm. The entire staff was so accommodating realizing that we were from out of town and really doted on our group of 11. We were a diverse group with folks from Taiwan, USA, Ireland, Italy and Great Britain so the language barrier was difficult at times but they worked with us. The food was amazing. The wine was delicious and the waiters were excellent. They kept our glasses filled and the wine coming! It's so nice to be welcomed with open arms in a foreign country and to see such tolerance for us as I'm sure we were not an "easy" group to deal with. :) Some memorable things to order if you go: 1) anchovies in tomato sauce, Iberian ham, Steak Tartare with avocado (just don't order it in Italian like I did (carpaccio) or you'll get gazpacho. Haha. My bad!), the cheese plate for dessert, and the list goes on! I don't think you can order a bad meal here. They even brought us specialty after-dinner shots for the group to try along with some complimentary desserts. The outside terrace is simply wonderful at night. The owner made a point of catering to us. It was a truly awesome first night in Madrid. Give it a try. Thanks to Restaurante Sal Negra for welcoming our diverse group with open arms. Harry, Party of 11. :) Saludos!

title_review: Very enjoyable restaurant in a quiet corner of Madrid
review_preview: We were in the area just before lunch time and based on the reviews decided on the spur of the moment to give Sal Negra a try. The restaurant is pleasantly arranged, especially the terrace with a nice mix of gently modernised classical dishes and...
review_full: We were in the area just before lunch time and based on the reviews decided on the spur of the moment to give Sal Negra a try. The restaurant is pleasantly arranged, especially the terrace with a nice mix of gently modernised classical dishes and quite surely a rather good wine selection, which we could not really take profit of, due to the circumstances. A very nice touch for us was that a large number of the dishes are available as half-rations, which allows to sample more food even if you're not really hungry. Service was very good, although the waiter seemed slightly taken aback by us wanting to share a few half-rations for starters, which for us was perfect: as it left some space for desserts. The food was generally very tasty and the overall impression very pleasant, the price range was reasonable, for being in Madrid and this area, With just a bit more 'sparkle' in the main dishes - perfectly fine, but not outstanding - this would have been a five-star rating, which I give rarely. We'll happily return to Sal Negra when the occassion arises.

There was not one vegetarian dish on the menu but the owner and the chef made some on the fly by substituting meat in their standard fare for a veggie option. title_review: Attention to details all around - food, service and design
review_preview: If you are a hummus lover, you know when you're tasting a fresh, well prepared hummus. La Hummuseria is one of those rare places in Europe that serves really good hummus, with excellent toppings. The hummus is reason enough to come and eat here, with...
review_full: If you are a hummus lover, you know when you're tasting a fresh, well prepared hummus. La Hummuseria is one of those rare places in Europe that serves really good hummus, with excellent toppings. The hummus is reason enough to come and eat here, with it's central location. However, there is much more to this place than hummus.  They serve wonderful tapas that go well with the main dishes on offer, great salads and tasty cocktails. Also they serve gluten free bread (and beer) for no extra charge. One of the things we loved about this place is that you can see and taste the effort and thought put into every aspect of the place and the food. Prices are good, atmosphere is great, if you are in the area, this is a great choice!

review_preview: We never miss a chance stop by here. Whether it’s our first or last stop of the night, we know we’re always going to have a great time. As soon as you walk in the door, your transported back 100 years with the look of...
review_full: We never miss a chance stop by here. Whether it’s our first or last stop of the night, we know we’re always going to have a great time. As soon as you walk in the door, your transported back 100 years with the look of their building. They’ve managed to keep the charm of the original hardware store that once stood at this location.  The wines are fantastic, with great selections in reds or whites. Plus we’re spoiled by the prices here, which is probably a quarter of the prices in the U.S. The have great beers too, fabulous mixed drinks, and Madrid’s famous Vermouths which you have to try. Adam is an authority on these, so be sure to ask his opinion. They also have master carvers there for their paper thin slices of Iberian ham and other delicious compliments tapas.  What we love most, is their wonderful staff makes you feel like you’re home. From their management to their bartenders and waitstaff, we have not found another place with such friendly people. Plus, they all speak great English! LOL  They truly are our good friends and feel like family.  We’ve even met and become friends with other customers from around the world here.  Please make this is stop on your visit and tell them MARK from the U.S. sent you. They’ll treat you like family too.

title_review: A Perfect Little Place with Lots of Character
review_preview: For those who do not know the spanish language well, a ferreteria is a hardware store which is the theme that will welcome you when you enter. It is full of original cabnitry and hardware in the space of what used to be the oldest...
review_full: For those who do not know the spanish language well, a ferreteria is a hardware store which is the theme that will welcome you when you enter. It is full of original cabnitry and hardware in the space of what used to be the oldest ferreteria in Madrid and is now a restauraunt. I have to say, this is a wonderful place. I did not eat dinner but had a couple of glasses of wine and some little bites to go along with the wine. The place has lots of character deeply rooted into the culture and community of Madrid, it has great wine, friendly staff and delicious food. It would be a mistake to not stop by in my opinion.

title_review: Go, just go! It is fabulous
review_preview: As the title suggests you should go if you are in MadridThis is great Spanish cookingIt is truly Spanish which means you need to accept 3 things;1. The earliest you can get a table is 8.30pm and you know what? No real...
review_full: As the title suggests you should go if you are in Madrid This is great Spanish cooking It is truly Spanish which means you need to accept 3 things; 1. The earliest you can get a table is 8.30pm and you know what? No real Spanish person is going to turn up before 10pm 2. You are going to need to embrace some broken Spanish (unless you are fluent) and that is a very good thing 3. It may be underwhelming from the outside but it is outstanding on the inside. Every dish we had was special.  Things you really need to try  1. The Iberian Ham 2. The herring with mango and avocado (yes your head says no but your taste buds will say Yes! Yes! Yes!) 3. The Galicia octopus 4. The sardine and tomatoes salad 5. The sorbets, either, the mint and mojito or the lemon. So fresh, bursting with flavor and the perfect way to end a warm Spanish evening. We were here on business but it would be equally suitable for a couple. Not so sure about families unless your children will eat more adventurous food and are used to being up late. If you have teenagers or older then worth a go. Good value for money. There were four of us and we were all comfortably full from sharing plates and desserts and enjoyed two bottles of wine for less that €200.

Emilio Garcia-Ortigosa (EGO) has done a wonderful job!! A best kept secret in Madrid!
